An air embolism is when air or gas enters the bloodstream and stops the flow of blood. An air embolism may not cause any symptoms or can lead to cardiovascular collapse and death.[^1] 

## Risks:[^2][^3][^4][^5]
- Heart defects
- Interventional radiology procedure 
- Central venous and arterial catheter placement and removal
- Angiography
- Traumatic injury 
- Surgical procedures: sitting craniotomy, C-section, & spinal surgery 
- IV infusions 
- Chest tube placement
- Endoscopy
- ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangio-Pancreatography)

## Signs & Symptoms:[^1][^3][^4][^5]
- Difficulty breathing
- Coughing
- Chest pain
- Very fast heart rate
- Seizures
- Loss of consciousness
- Confusion
- Arm and/or leg weakness
- Paralysis on one side of the body
- Facial droop 
- Difficulty speaking

## Healthcare Provider Questions:
1.	How will air embolisms be prevented in your surgery?
2.	Are you at risk for air embolisms? 
3.	How will air embolisms be prevented in central & arterial line insertions & removals?
4.	How can air embolisms be prevented from an IV infusion?

 __Use the Hospital Plan of Care form to advocate and ask questions about your loved one.__

[The Hospital Plan of Care form](https://patientsafetymovement.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/POC-Blank-April-19.pdf "The Hospital Plan of Care form")

[Guide to Medical Care at a Distance](https://patientsafetymovement.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Guide-to-Medical-Care-at-a-Distance.pdf "Guide to Medical Care at a Distance")

## Prevention:[^1][^3][^4][^5]
- Adequate hydration to prevent low central venous pressure.
- Avoid a surgical site above the heart (if possible). 
- Prone or "park bench" surgical position instead of sitting positions.
- Trendelenburg position (if possible) or supine during central venous catheter insertion & removal.
- Not breathing in during central venous catheter insertion & removal
- Valsalva maneuver (if possible) or breathing out with central venous catheter removal.
- After removal of central venous catheter, cover with impermeable dressing and apply 5-10 minutes of pressure.
- Lying supine for 30 minutes after central venous catheter is removed 

[Venous Air Embolism: Rare but Fatal EMRA](https://www.emra.org/emresident/article/venous-air-embolism/ "Venous Air Embolism: Rare but Fatal EMRA")

[^1]: Gordy S, Rowell S. Vascular air embolism. *Int J Crit Illn Inj Sci.* 2013;3(1):73-76. doi:[10.4103/2229-5151.109428] https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3665124/. Accessed December 14, 2018.

[^2]: O’Brien JJ, Butterworth J, Hammon JW, et al. Cerebral emboli during cardiac surgery in children. *Anesthesiology* 1997; 11:1063-1069. http://anesthesiology.pubs.asahq.org/article.aspx?articleid=1948337. Accessed January 11, 2019.

[^3]: Feil M. Reducing risk of air embolism associated with central vascular line devices. *Pa Patient Saf Advis* 2012 June; 9(2):58-64. http://patientsafety.pa.gov/ADVISORIES/Pages/201206_58.aspx. Accessed January 7, 2019.

[^4]: McCarthy CJ, Behravesh S, Naidu SG, Oklu R. Air Embolism: Practical tips for prevention and treatment. *J Clin Med.* 2016;5(11):93. doi:10.3390/jcm5110093. Accessed December 13, 2018.

[^5]: Mirski MA, Lele AV, Fitzsimmons L, Toung TJK. Diagnosis and treatment of vascular embolism. *Anesthesiology* 2007;1(106): 164-177. http://anesthesiology.pubs.asahq.org/article.aspx?articleid=1923071. Accessed January 11, 2019.
